text_headline: Silay is fortified with a palisade.
text_description: Silay is fortified with a palisade.

media_caption: Castillo de San Vicente Ferrer in Maribojoc, Bohol, 2016
media_credit: (Photo by Claire Jabines, Bohol Provincial Tourism Office)
text_description: Punta Cruz’s Fort of San Vicente Ferrer in Maribojoc, Bohol is completed.

media_caption: Church of the Santo Niño in Tondo, Manila, 1993
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: After 1863, the Tondo neoclassical church is completed, designed by Luciano Oliver (active c. 1854-1873).

media_caption: Casa Gorordo in the Parian, Cebu City, 2015
text_description: Fr Juan Isidro de Gorordo acquires a house in Parian, Cebu, built in the mid-19th century by Arch Alejandro Reynes (b. ca 1820). Acquired by Ramon Aboitiz Foundation, Inc. (RAFI) in 1983, it is now the Casa Gorordo house museum.

text_headline: MUSEO ILOILO
text_description: Museo Iloilo is completed, designed by Sergio Penasales (b. 1935).
The first Manila Cathedral is burnt and replaced by a provisional structure.
Fr Diego de Moxica, OSA builds a convento of stone in Pasig before he dies this year.

media_caption: Escuela Pia, popularly called Escolapia, 2017
text_description: The construction of the escuela pia at Taal, Batangas is completed.

media_caption: Church of Santo Domingo in Intramuros, Manila, ca 1910
text_description: The newly built façade of Santo Domingo in the neoclassical style, said to have been patterned after Christopher Wren’s St. Paul’s Cathedral in London, collapses. It stood for only a little over a year.

media_caption: San Jose de Placer Church and Lacson House in the foreground, ca 1920
text_description: As a result of the opening of the Iloilo international port, Iloilo grows rapidly and large bahay na bato are built in the area between the Church of San Jose and Fort San Pedro.

media_caption: Main altar of the neo-Gothic Santo Domingo Church
text_description: The fifth Santo Domingo church, begun 1864, is completed. It is designed by European-trained Felix Arroyo Roxas, Sr. (Ca 1820 - Ca 1890) in Neogothic style. It is destroyed on Dec 21, 1941 by Japanese bombs.

media_caption: Aduana or Customs House, also Intendencia or City Administration in Intramuros, 1899
text_description: The Neo-classical Aduana in Intramuros, begun in 1832, is renovated 1874. It replaces the Alcaiceria de San Fernando in Binondo as the Customs House.

media_caption: Church of Santa Ana in Molo, Iloilo, 2013
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: The Molo Church of Santa Ana is substantially completed but work on the church interior continues to the 1920s when the neogothic retablos of the church are completed. It is marked by NHI in 1992.

media_caption: Church of Santa Catalina de Alejandria in Carcar, Cebu, 2003
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: Carcar church, Cebu, constructed under Fr. Antonio Manglano, OSA, and begun in 1860, is completed under Fr Manuel Fernandez, OSA.

media_caption: Santos-Bautista House, 2017
text_description: The Bautista House with the caryatids in Malolos, Bulacan is completed.

media_caption: Carcel de Cebu in Cebu City, 2015, now repurposed as a museum
text_description: The Carcel de Cebu, begun in 1863, is completed, designed by Domingo de Escondrillas (Active: 1855-1893).

media_caption: Basilica Minore of San Martin de Tours in Taal, Batangas, ca 1990
text_description: The Taal Church of San Martin in Batangas is completed, designed by municipal architect of Manila, Luciano Oliver. It is elevated to basilica minore on Oct 22, 1948. Restored in 1972, it is declared a National Shrine in 1974 by NHI.

media_caption: Cathedral of Santa Isabel de Hungria in Jaro, Iloilo, 2015
text_description: Jaro catherdral dedicated to Santa Isabel de Hungria is completed, after Augustinians hand over the parish to Mariano Cuartero, named bishop of Jaro in 1867.

media_caption: Church of San Miguel in Samboan, Cebu, 2009
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: Samboan’s Church of San Miguel and Jacob’s Ladderin Cebu are completed.

media_caption: Depiction of the Negritos, ca 1590
media_credit: (Boxer Codex, The Lilly Library Digital Collections)
text_description: The Spanish melt down silver, mostly church ornaments, to pay a ransom to the British to spare Intramuros from destruction. Nonetheless, British troops ransack Intramuros. Many works of art and precious objects are destroyed and documents destroyed or looted. Among those believed to have been looted is the Boxer Codex, which has 16th century illustrations of native Filipinos, like the Tagalog, Visayan, Zambal, and Ayta.

media_caption: Balanghai CE 320
text_description: Large edge-pegged plank boats popularly called “balanghay” are used for travel and residence. Discovered in the 1970s in Butuan City are the earliest dated boats found in the Philippines.

media_caption: Maitum jar
media_credit: National Museum of the Philippines Collection
text_description: In Maitum Cave, Saranggani, humans leave anthropomorphic burial jars, gall beads, bracelets, and other ornaments for the deceased.
Hilton Hotel on UN Ave, designed by Carlos Arguelles (1919-2008) and Welton Beckett (1902-1969), is inaugurated.

text_headline: American architect and city planner Daniel H. Burnham (1846-1912) arrives in the Philippines upon the invitation of Com. William Cameron Forbes (r. 1909-1913).
text_description: American architect and city planner Daniel H. Burnham (1846-1912) arrives in the Philippines upon the invitation of Com. William Cameron Forbes (r. 1909-1913). He tours Manila and Baguio to prepare plans for the capital city and the “hill station,” Baguio.
The San Miguel Church in Manila is rebuilt in the Neoromanesque style.
The Philippine School of Arts and Trade (now TUP) is built in the Mission Revival style.
Ateneo de Naga main building in Naga City is completed, known for its Grecian temple entrance.
Post-WWII reconstruction begins with funds coming from the War Damage Claims office and with material from WWII surplus.
The Iglesia Filipina Independiente’s Cathedral of the Santo Niño on Taft Ave., designed by Carlos Arguelles, is completed.
The Iglesia ni Cristo (INC), Main Temple in Quezon City is completed.
The earthquake causes much damage. The Nevada Hotel and the Hyatt in Baguio collapse. The historic Dagupan Cathedral is damaged and roads in Pangasinan are impassable.
Ateneo Professional Schools Makati City, designed by the firm of Francisco Mañosa, is completed. It shows the firm’s signature Neovernacular.

World Exchange Tower in Binondo, Manila designed by American architect Michael Graves, is completed. The project ushers the trend of hiring well-known foreign architects for Philippine projects that strive to be “iconic.”
Pacific Plaza Tower in Fort Bonifacio, designed by Architectonica, is completed.
Surigao church is built.
Lourdes Grotto on Mirador Hill is constructed by Fr Jose Algue, SJ, director of the Manila Observatory. Statue of Our Lady of Lourdes, carved and signed by Isabelo Tampinco, is placed in the grotto.
Baguio Central School, established in 1898, is moved to a site near the Civic Center. The new building is in Neoclassical style with a Grecian portico.
Far Eastern University, Manila, is completed in Art Deco.
The reconstruction of Assumption College on Herran St. (Pedro Gil) begun in 1946 is completed, following the pre-WWII Gothic style.
The Central Bank of the Philippines in Manila and the Asian Institute of Management (AIM) Bldg. in Makati City, both designed by Gabriel Formoso (1915-1996), are completed.
The second ADB headquarters, designed by Skidmore, Owings and Merrill (SOM) with partner Engracio L. Mariano and Associates, is completed.

The Victorias Chapel of St. Joseph the Worker in Victorias Sugar Central in Negros Occidental is completed. Designed by the New York firm of Antonin Raymond & Ladislav Rado, the chapel is a pioneer in the Modernist style. International and local artists work on the structure. Ade de Bethuene designs the mural with assistance from local artisans and Alfonso Ossorio paints the murals. The mural in the sanctuary, dubbed “The Angry Christ” is controversial.
The first Asian Development Bank (ADB) headquarters in Pasay City is completed. It is acquired by the Department of Foreign Affairs (DFA), when ADB moves to new quarters in 1986.
Benguet Mining Corporation Bldg. in Pasig City, designed by Locsin, is completed. Its use of Benguet stone and step-like design evokes the Cordillera rice terraces.
New construction experiences a slow down as a result of the crisis.
The Supreme Court on Taft Ave in Manila, designed by Parsons, is built.
Benitez Hall and Malcolm Hall at the UP Diliman campus, both designed by Juan Arellano, are completed.
UCCP church in Baguio is constructed. It is marked by NHCP in 2012.
Vision Theater in Cebu, begun in the 1930s, is completed under Engr Agustin Jereza.
Tektite Towers and Renaissance Tower, both in Pasig City and both designed by Villarosa, are completed.
Essensa Towers in The Fort, Taguig City, designed by IM Pei (Pei, Cobb, Freed & Partners), is completed.

A chapel for Southwestern University in Cebu, Ampoanan sa Kalinaw ug Kinaadman, designed by National Artist Napoleon Abueva, is completed. It is regarded more as a large sculptural work rather than a building.

media_caption: The auditorium of the Ateneo de Manila in Intramuros where the young Jose Rizal must have watched performances
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of Ambeth R. Ocampo Collection)
text_description: Ateneo Municipal builds a campus on Arsobispo and Anda Sts; it occupies the block until Santa Lucia.
Carnival Queen Theater is built in Baguio.

As a result of fires and bombardment, the southern side of Manila, especially Intramuros and the Taft Corridor buildings, are devastated. Manila is cited as the second most devastated city after WWII, second only to Warsaw.
Melchor Hall in UP Diliman, QC, designed by Cesar H. Concio, is completed.
Cebu IT Park, begun in 2001, on the former Lahug Airport is completed.
LJ Hormillosa bldg in Iloilo is completed in the International style.
Nurses Home on Taft Ave, designed by Tomas Mapua (1888-1965) in Neorennaisance style, is completed.
The National Press Club in Manila, designed by Angel Nakpil, is completed.

media_caption: Calle Real in Intramuros flanked on the left by San Agustin Monastery and on the right by the Augustinian Provincial House
text_description: The Augustinians establish the Monasterio de San Pablo, popularly known as San Agustín, at the site alotted them by Legazpi, along Calle Real.
A palisade is built at La Caldera (Recodo), Zamboanga.
A provisional church in Butuan is completed by Ledesma.
Jesuits build a church and residence at the Marikina hacienda.
The Neoclassical Sorsogon Capitol is completed.
The World Health Organization Bldg., designed by Alfredo Luz, along Taft Ave. is completed.

media_caption: Sheik Karimul Makdum Mosque, in Simunul, Tawi-Tawi, known as the oldest mosque in the country, 2010
text_description: Attributed to Makhdum, the first Mosque in the Philippines is built on Simunul Island, Tawi-tawi.
Arcadio Arellano (1872-1920) designs the Ariston Bautista Lin house in Quiapo.
Philippine Atomic Research Center, designed by Cresenciano de Castro, in UP Diliman, is completed.

media_caption: Architectural drawings of a bahay na bato
text_description: During the reconstruction of Manila shortly after the fire, the first example of the bahay na bato is built, a work by Sedeño and Bp Salazar, who rebuild the bishop’s house in stone and wood.

media_caption: Malate Church, ca 1920
text_description: A stone convento is built in Malate by the Augustinians.

media_caption: Banaue Rice Terraces, ca 1990
text_description: The rice terraces in Bunghalian, Ifugao are constructed.
Casino Español inaugurates a building on Taft Ave., designed by Arcadio and Juan Arellano.

media_caption: The base of the tower of Nuestra Señora de Guia, inside Bastion de San Diego in Intramuros, Manila, 2016
text_description: Intramuros’ first stone defense, Nuestra Señora de Guia tower, is constructed by Sedeño at the southwestern corner of the city of Manila.
Zamboanga Normal School, begun in 1917, is completed as the permanent home for the Provincial Normal School established in 1914.

media_caption: Fort Santiago, ca 1920
text_description: The first provisional fortifications of Manila and Fort Santiago are built.

The Legarda Elementary School in the French Renaissance style, noted for its Mansard roof and dormer windows, is completed. Its architect is Andres Luna de San Pedro (1887-1952), son of the painter Juan Luna.
Celso Ledesma Mansion in Iloilo City is completed in Beaux Arts style with art deco touches. It is known for the eagles that decorate its fence.
The Javellana Bldg in Iloilo City, Neoclassical in style, is completed.
Casa Vallejo in Baguio opens, repurposing dormitories originally built for he workers who built Baguio.

media_caption: View of the Anda Monument and Fort Santiago before World War II
text_description: Gov-Gen Dasmariñas rebuilds Fort Santiago, raising a stone wall along the shore connecting Santiago and the tower Nuestra Señora de Guia. The walls of Intramuros are rebuilt, reinforced, renovated over the centuries and until 1862.

media_caption: Church of Santo Domingo in Intramuros, Manila, ca 1910
text_description: In Intramuros, a church of stone dedicated to Santo Domingo de Guzman is completed. This is the second Dominican church.

media_caption: Church of Santa Ana in Manila, one of the earliest missions of the Franciscans, 1993
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: The Church of Santa Ana in Intramuros is completed. Designed by Sedeño and following the prototype Il Gesù in Rome, construction begins in 1590. It is the first Renaissance-Baroque church built in the Philippines.The church’s stone vault collapses during the 1600 earthquake. It is subsequently demolished in 1626 to make room for the first San Ignacio church.
The Negros Oriental Capitol in Dumaguete City is completed.
The Ledesma Residence in Jaro, Iloilo is constructed in the Neoclassical style around this time.

media_caption: Prewar Antipolo Church and Convent
media_credit: (Our New Possessions by Trumbull White, John E. Hoham & Co, 1898)
text_description: Antipolo is turned over to the Jesuits by the Franciscans. Diego Garcia SJ founds the prototype of a Jesuit Reduction in Latin America Antipolo has a church, convento, schools for boys and girls, hospital, and lots marked out on a grid plan for native dwellings.

media_caption: San Agustin Church in Intramuros, Manila, 1993
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: San Agustin Church and monastery in Intramuros, begun in 1586, are completed. Designed by architect Juan Macias, the church is closer in style to the Renaissance.

media_caption: Facade of Morong Church in Rizal with classical columns, 1991
text_description: Morong church, Rizal is completed. Its facade is renovated in the 19th century, following the design of Bartolome Palatino, a master builder from Paete, Laguna.

media_caption: Spanish-period Fort San Felipe in Cavite
text_description: Fort San Felipe, Cavite, is built. In the early 20th century, Americans demolish it to build a naval base, but retain the fort’s gate and the flanking curtain walls.

media_caption: Shrine of Our Lady of Caysasay, 2017
text_description: The Augustinian shrine church to Our Lady of Caysasay, Taal, Batangas, is built.

media_caption: Fort San Pedro, demolished in the 1900s
text_description: Fort San Pedro in Iloilo is built as defense against the Dutch.

media_caption: Facade of Church of San Gregorio Magno in Majayjay, Laguna, 1993
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: Majayjay church, begun ca 1616, is completed. It is reconstructed around 1707. It is the largest Franciscan church and convento in Laguna.
The Colegio de Manila in Intramuros is damaged by earthquake.
Casa Ordaveza in Majayjay, Laguna is constructed.
San Marcelino Church designed in the Neoclassical style by Luna de San Pedro is completed.

media_caption: Puente de España, ca 1920, later replaced by Jones Bridge
text_description: Puente Grande de España is completed. Spanning the Pasig and connecting Intramuros with Binondo, its last reconstruction and repair is in the 19th century.
Casa de España, aka Casino Español and the S. Villanueva Bldg are constructed in Iloilo.

media_caption: Prewar Antipolo Church and Convent
media_credit: (Our New Possessions by Trumbull White, John E. Hoham & Co, 1898)
text_description: Antipolo church in Rizal, begun in 1630 and designed by Juan de Salazar, SJ, is completed. It is renovated in 1863 by Arch Luciano Oliver. Damaged during WWII, it will be rebuilt in a modern idiom after WWII. It houses the black image of the Nuestra Señora de la Paz y Buenviaje, given to the church in 1632.

media_caption: Church of Nuestra Señora de la Asuncion in Maragondon, Cavite, 1994
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: Maragondon’s Church of La Asuncion de la Virgen in Cavite and the Santa Cruz church in Marinduque are completed.

media_caption: Outer walls of Fort Pilar
text_description: Fort San Jose (later renamed Pilar) in Zamboanga is built by Melchor de Vera SJ (1585-1646). It is demolished in 1663, when the Spanish garrison is called to Manila to meet the threat of an attack by Koxinga.

media_caption: Facade of the Church of Santiago in Paete, Laguna, 1993
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: Paete Church of Santiago in Laguna is completed.

media_caption: Baptistry altar walls covered with shells, Church of the Inmaculada Concepcion, Guiuan, Eastern Samar, 2018
text_description: The Guiuan Church of La Inmaculada Concepcion in Samar, probably the second and more permanent church, is completed around this year.

media_caption: Shrine of Nuestra Señora del Pilar at Fort Pilar, 2009
media_credit: (National Historical Commission of the Philippines Collection)
text_description: Fort Pilar in Zamboanga is built by military architect Juan de Ciscara at the site of Fort San Jose; which demolished in 1663.

media_caption: Jesuit House of 1730 in Cebu City, 2015
text_description: The Jesuit house at Zulueta St, Parian district, Cebu is completed. It is the oldest dated bahay na bato in Cebu.
The Dominican architect, Roque Ruaño, completes the UST main building at España Ave. on a 10-hectare lot acquired earlier. The building is in Art Deco and is designed to survive earthquakes.

media_caption: Interior of the 1889 San Ignacio Church in Intramuros, Manila
text_description: The first San Ignacio church at Calle Real del Palacio, begun in 1626, is completed; it is designed in the Baroque style by the Italian Gianantonio Campioni, SJ (1592-1651).

media_caption: Church of San Pedro y San Pablo in Loboc, Bohol, 2003
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: The first stone church of Loboc, Bohol. is completed around this year.

media_caption: Church of Santa Maria Magdalena in Kawit, Cavite, 1994
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: Completed this year are the Kawit Church of Santa Maria Magdalena in Cavite, the Santa Cruz church in Manila, and the Cainta Church of Nuestra Señora de la Luz in Rizal.

media_caption: Fort San Pedro in Cebu, ca 1920
media_credit: (Cebuano Studies Center, University of San Carlos)
text_description: Fort San Pedro in Cebu is renovated. The site is said to be the place where Legazpi had built a triangular palisade in 1565.
Palace Theater and the Dominican Sisters’ building, both in Iloilo, are constructed.

media_caption: Church and Fort of San Agustin in Cuyo, Palawan, 2005
media_credit: (Photos by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: Cuyo church and fort in Palawan are completed by Juan de San Severo, OAR.

media_caption: Church of San Pedro y San Pablo in Loboc, Bohol, 2003
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: The second Loboc Church of San Pedro y San Pablo in Bohol is completed.

media_caption: Church of San Luis Obispo de Tolosa in Lucban, Quezon, 2013
text_description: Lucban Church is completed.

media_caption: Prewar Ayuntamiento or City Hall in Intramuros
media_credit: (Philippine Picture Post Cards: 1900-1920 by Jonathan Best, The Bookmark, Inc, 1994)
text_description: The second Ayuntamiento or city hall of Manila is completed.

media_caption: Basilica Minore of the Santo Niño
media_credit: (Cebuano Studies Center, University of San Carlos)
text_description: The Church of the Santo Niño (presently Basilica Minore del Santo Niño) in Cebu is completed under Juan de Albarran, OSA.

media_caption: San Francisco Church, destroyed during World War II
text_description: Church of Nuestra Señora de los Angeles, more popularly known as San Francisco in Intramuros, is constructed. The church is destroyed during WWII.

media_caption: Church of San Miguel Arcangel in Tayabas, Quezon
text_description: A stone church built by the Franciscans in 1600 in Tayabas, Quezon is ruined by earthquake, most likely a consequence of Mt. Banahaw’s eruption.

media_caption: Augustinian-built Church of San Juan de Sahagun in Tigbauan, Iloilo, 2007
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: The Augustinian Church of San Juan de Sahagun in Tigbauan, Iloilo with its unique plateresque façade is completed around this time.

media_caption: Church of San Bartolome Apostol in Nagcarlan, Laguna, 1993
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: Nagcarlan Church in Laguna church is completed.

media_caption: Church of San Pedro y San Pablo in Calasiao, Pangasinan, 2014
text_description: Calasiao church in Pangasinan, begun in 1753, is most likely completed this year.

media_caption: Fort San Antonio Abad in Manila, captured by US troops, 1898
media_credit: (San Diego Air and Space Museum, John Tewell Collection)
text_description: Fort San Antonio Abad is constructed after the British leave. It replaces an earlier fort used as the polverin or gunpowder depot, which is previously located inside Intramuros. On Aug 13, 1898, Americans occupy the fort and raise the US flag on Philippine soil, the first site where the American flag is raised.

media_caption: Church of San Pedro de Alcantara and Diocesan Shrine of Nuestra Señora de los Dolores de Turumba in Pakil, Laguna, 2016
text_description: Pakil’s Church of San Diego Alcantara in Laguna is completed. It is the site of the seven fiestas of Nuestra Señora de Dolores, known for the Turumba.

media_caption: Cathedral of San Pedro in Tuguegarao in Cagayan, 2003
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: Tuguegarao Church of Santo Domingo in Cagayan, begun in 1762, is completed.
St Paul Manila’s Chapel of the Crucified Christ in Art Deco, designed by Luna de San Pedro, is completed.

media_caption: Church of San Agustin in Paoay, Ilocos Norte, 2012
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: Pao-ay church, Ilocos Norte is started. It takes a long time to complete. It is reinaugurated in 1896, when work on the ceiling paintings is completed.

media_caption: Church of Santa Monica in Pan-ay, Capiz, 2013
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: The second Pan-ay Church of Santa Monica in Capiz is completed; it replaces an earlier church, constructed ca 1692. The second church is reconstructed in 1884.
The Mercado-Marasigan residence in San Juan, Batangas, is completed.

media_caption: Church of Nuestra Señora de la Porteria in Daraga, Albay, ca 1990
text_description: Daraga Church of Nuestra Señora de Porteria in Albay begins construction.

media_caption: Facade of the Church of San Matias in Tumauini, Isabela, 2007
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: The brick church of San Matias in Tumauini, Isabela starts construction, supposedly under friar-architect, Antonio Lobato, OP (1724-1794).

media_caption: Church of San Ildefonso in Tanay, Rizal, 2012
text_description: The Tanay Church of San Idelfonso in Rizal is completed. Its altars are Rococo.

media_caption: Tanjosoy-Bautista-de los Santos House in Malolos City, with art nouveau influence, 2017
text_description: The Tanjosoy-Bautista-De los Santos house in Malolos is built.

media_caption: Restored Casa de Comunidad de Tayabas in Quezon, 2011
text_description: The Casa de Communidad in Tayabas, Quezon is built of stone under Gob Salvador Flores de San Francisco. It is repaired in 1810 by Gob Lorenzo de los Reyes, then remodelled and expanded in 1831-1835 by Gob Diego Enriquez.

media_caption: El Hogar building, ca 1920
text_description: El Hogar is inaugurated.

media_caption: Facade of the Palacio del Gobernador in Intramuros, Manila
media_credit: (Fiestas en Manila Año 1825 by Justa Moreno Gaarbayo, Patrimonio Nacional, 1977)
text_description: The Real Audiencia, formerly housed in the Palacio del Gobernador, acquires its own property in Intramuros. Soon after the Audiencia building is started.

media_caption: Exterior and bell tower of Vigan Cathedral, 2012
text_description: Vigan’s Cathedral of San Pablo is completed around this time.

media_caption: Brick facade of the Church of Santa Monica in Sarrat, Ilocos Norte, 1995
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: Before this year, Sarrat church, Ilocos Norte is completed. It will be rebuilt in 1848.

media_caption: acade and bell tower of the Church of San Guillermo in Dalaguete, Cebu, 2003
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: Dalaguete church in Cebu, begun in 1801, is completed. It has rococo altars.
Manila Jockey Club on Felix Huertas St. is completed. Its architect is Juan Nakpil (1899-1986).

media_caption: Church of Nuestra Señora del Patrocinio de Maria in Boljoon, Cebu, 2009
media_credit: (National Historical Commission of the Philippines Collection)
text_description: Church of the Patrocino in Boljoon, Cebu is constructed. Rococo motifs are evident on the retablo, considered an exemplary of this style.

media_caption: Malacañan Palace
media_credit: (Old Manila by Ramon Ma. Zaragoza, Oxford University Press, 1990)
text_description: Malacañan is built by Don Antonia Dias Conde around this year; later it is bought by Luis Rocha in 1796; then by Jose Miguel Fomento in 1802, until Gov-Gen Juan Antonio Martinez acquires it for a rest house.

media_caption: Church of the Santisima Trinidad and bell tower, 2012
text_description: Loay’s Church of the Santisima Trinidad is built. The convento follows in 1838, the bell tower in 1865 and the cement portico façade in the early 20th century. Damaged by the 2013 earthquakes, the church is being restored.

media_caption: Main altar of Argao Church in Cebu, ca 1990
text_description: The Argao Church of San Miguel in Cebu, begun Ca 1788, is completed. It has rococo altars.

media_caption: Prewar Cathedral of San Vitalis in Cebu City
text_description: The Cebu Cathedral (Church of San Vitalis), begun in 1734, is completed. It is damaged by WWII and reconstructed in 1959 by Jose Zaragosa (1912-1994).
St. Clement’s Church in Iloilo in Art Deco is constructed under the Redemptorists.

text_headline: Teatro Filipino at Echague in Quiapo is built.
text_description: Teatro Filipino at Echague in Quiapo is built.

media_caption: Entrance and mortuary chapel of Paco Cemetery, ca 1990
text_description: Built for the victims of a cholera epidemic, the oval-shaped Paco Cemetery in Manila is completed.

media_caption: Calle Colon, early 1900s
media_credit: (Cebuano Studies Center, University of San Carlos)
text_description: The establishment of non-Spanish trading houses and businesses in the Philippines, especially in Binondo, Iloilo and Cebu, brings new construction materials and tools from Europe and the USA, such as fabric and stamped metal ceilings, zinc roofing from England, ice-boxes from USA, and French household bric-a-brac.

media_caption: Mercado House in Bustos, Bulacan of carved stone, capiz windows, and wooden balustrade
text_description: The Mercado residence in Bustos, Bulacan is completed.
Ellinwood church in Malate, Manila is constructed. It is in the Neogothic style favored by the Protestants.

media_caption: Church of the Nuestra Señora de Candelaria in Silang, Cavite, 1994
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: Silang’s Church of Nuestra Señora de Candelaria is completed under the supervision of Juan Salazar, SJ (1582-1645). Its Baroque retablos are designated as a National Treasure by the National Museum in 2016.

media_caption: Holy Rosary Minor Seminary in Naga City, 2003
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: The Casa de Clerigos and Seminario Conciliar, later known as Holy Rosary Seminary, in Naga is constructed around this time.

media_caption: Church of San Francisco de Asis in Naga, Cebu, 2013
text_description: Naga’s Church of San Francisco de Asis in Cebu is completed.
Manila’s City Hall, begun in 1930 and designed by Toledo, is completed.

media_caption: Colegio de San Juan de Letran, 1887
text_description: The Dominicans complete a school building for 200 students for Letran. Made of stone, it is located near the Church of Santo Domingo. Acquiring a lot at the corner of the Baluarte de San Gabriel in 1688, Letran moves to this site, where it has remained since.

media_caption: Facade details of Church of Santo Tomas de Villanueva in Miag-ao, Iloilo, 2013
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda,Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: The Church of Santo Tomas de Villanueva in Miag-ao, Iloilo is completed with rococo morifs. It is declared World Heritage Site in 1993.

media_caption: Facade of the Palacio del Gobernador in Intramuros, Manila
media_credit: (Fiestas en Manila Año 1825 by Justa Moreno Gaarbayo, Patrimonio Nacional, 1977)
text_description: The facade of the Palacio del Gobernador in Intramuros, built under the governorship of Fausto Cruzat y Gongora (1690-1701), is renovated in the neoclassical style. It is ruined by an 1863 earthquake, then abandoned in 1880 after another earthquake.
The Dr. Luis U. Santos residence in Malolos, Bulacan is completed. The house is eclectic in style but Art Deco dominates. The sala is dominated by a mural painting by Fernando Amorsolo.
Augustinians build a church at Siaro (Carcar, Cebu).
Loakan Airport in Baguio is completed.

media_caption: Puente de Malagonlong
text_description: Puente de Malagonlong in Tayabas, Quezon, begun 1841 under Fr Antonio Mateo, OFM, is completed.

media_caption: Manila City Hall, ca 1950
text_headline: MANILA CITY HALL
text_description: The Manila City Hall, designed by Toledo in the Neoclassical style, is completed.
The American Embassy along Roxas Blvd, Manila, designed by Juan Arellano, is constructed.

text_headline: The Maxino residence in Unisan, Quezon is completed.
text_description: The Maxino residence in Unisan, Quezon is completed.

The Lopez Streamline Moderne “boathouse,” designed by F.H. Ocampo, is completed. It is declared a heritage house by NHI in 2002 and marked in 2004. Restored, it is the regional training center of ABS-CBN Visayas.

media_caption: Map: Philippine archipelago
text_description: The name Filipinas is extended to the rest of the Philippine archipelago, creating a territory now known as the Philippines where the traditions of European architecture will take root.

The Meralco headquarters on San Marcelino St Manila, built in Art Deco and designed by Luna de San Pedro, is completed. Its facade is decorated with the sculpture, The Furies, by Monti. The building is now demolished.
Avenue Hotel and Theater is built on Rizal Ave in Manila.

media_caption: Facade of Morong Church in Rizal with classical columns, 1991
text_description: The facade of Morong’s Church of San Geronimo in Rizal, designed by Bartolome Palatino (1787-after 1853) of Paete and begun in 1850, is completed.
The Magdalena Bldg in Iloilo, designed by Jose Tantoy Locsin, is built.

media_caption: Prewar cottages in Camp John Hay
text_headline: CAMP JOHN HAY
text_description: A summer residence for the American commanding general is built in Camp John Hay.

text_headline: Church of Santa Rita at Balingasag, Misamis Occidental is constructed.
text_description: Church of Santa Rita at Balingasag, Misamis Occidental is constructed.
Admiral Apartments on Roxas Blvd, Manila, begun in 1938, is completed.

text_headline: The stone Church of San Bartolome in Catbalogan, Samar is completed before this year.
text_description: The stone Church of San Bartolome in Catbalogan, Samar is completed before this year.

text_headline: The Alcaiceria de San Fernando in Binondo, designed by Fr. Lucas de Jesus Maria, is completed.
text_description: The Alcaiceria de San Fernando in Binondo, designed by Fr. Lucas de Jesus Maria, is completed. It is an octagonal building, which serves as the silk market and temporary residence of traders from south China.

text_headline: Fort Nuestra Señora del Triunfo y de la Victoria is completed in Misamis (Ozamis City) by Jose Ducos, SJ.
text_description: Fort Nuestra Señora del Triunfo y de la Victoria is completed in Misamis (Ozamis City) by Jose Ducos, SJ.

text_headline: The Palapag Church of San Ignacio and its fortress in Samar is built around this year.
text_description: The Palapag Church of San Ignacio and its fortress in Samar is built around this year.

text_headline: Some churches in Samar are abandoned for about a decade until the Franciscans take charge in 1804.
text_description: Some churches in Samar are abandoned for about a decade until the Franciscans take charge in 1804. Recollects take over Bohol and western Mindanao. The diocesan or secular clergy of Manila take charge of Cavite and Marinduque.

text_headline: Naga’s Cathedral of San Juan, in Camarines Sur, begun at the initiative of Bp Bernardo de la Concepcion, OFM in 1808, is completed.
text_description: Naga’s Cathedral of San Juan, in Camarines Sur, begun at the initiative of Bp Bernardo de la Concepcion, OFM in 1808, is completed. It is restored in 1890, and then again in1987-1988 under Abp. Leonardo Legazpi, OP.

text_headline: The Tayabas Church of San Miguel in Laguna is completed, after extensive renovation and expansion under Fr. Benito de la Pila OFM, begun in 1856.
text_description: The Tayabas Church of San Miguel in Laguna is completed, after extensive renovation and expansion under Fr. Benito de la Pila OFM, begun in 1856. The church is raised to a basilica minore in 1988 and declared a historical landmark in 1972 and 1986 by NHI.

text_headline: The Tetuan Church of San Ignacio in Zamboanga is built.
text_description: The Tetuan Church of San Ignacio in Zamboanga is built.

text_headline: The Cuartel de Santa Lucia, along the western flank of Intramuros is constructed, following the plans of Tomas Sanz, as the barracks for the Artelleria de la Montaña.
text_description: The Cuartel de Santa Lucia, along the western flank of Intramuros is constructed, following the plans of Tomas Sanz, as the barracks for the Artelleria de la Montaña.

media_caption: Plaza Rizal fronting the Zamboanga City Hall, 2015
text_headline: ZAMBOANGA CITY HALL
text_description: Zamboanga City Hall is completed and becomes the seat of the Moro Province, Department of Mindanao and Sulu, in 1914.

text_headline: Parian church of San Juan Bautista in Cebu, built by the mestizo Chinese diocesan clergy early in the century, is demolished.
text_description: Parian church of San Juan Bautista in Cebu, built by the mestizo Chinese diocesan clergy early in the century, is demolished. After a long drawn conflict with the convent of Santo Niño over jurisdiction, the parish of San Juan is ordered disbanded and demoted to a visita under Santo Niño.

media_caption: The Manila Grand Opera House on Avenida Rizal, Manila ca 1920s
text_headline: MANILA GRAND OPERA HOUSE
text_description: The Manila Grand Opera House in Manila is completed.

text_headline: BAGUIO GENERAL HOSPITAL
text_description: The Baguio Gen Hospital is rebuilt on a larger and grander scale (1941), seven years after Pres Quezon promises to upgrade the hospital in 1937.

media_caption: Cultural Center of the Philippines
text_headline: CULTURAL CENTER OF THE PHILIPPINES
text_description: The Cultural Center of the Philippines, designed by Leandro Locsin, is inaugurated. Later, other buildings by Locsin will be built near it, like the Philippine International Convnetion Center and the Folk Arts Theater.

media_caption: Imelda Marcos, center, with the winner and candidates of Miss Universe 1974
text_headline: FOLK ARTS THEATER
text_description: Folk Arts Theater (later the Tanghalang Francisco Baltazar), designed by Locsin, is completed in time for the Miss Universe Pageant.

text_headline: As a result of the Jesuits’ expulsion, some churches and buildings remain abandoned.
text_description: As a result of the Jesuits’ expulsion, some churches and buildings remain abandoned. New administrators are assigned to these places, who in time will repair and renovate the buildings, in some cases obliterating or obscuring the Jesuit heritage.

text_headline: The Archbishop of Manila takes over the abandoned Jesuit college building and adjoining church in Intramuros and uses them for a seminary.
text_description: The Archbishop of Manila takes over the abandoned Jesuit college building and adjoining church in Intramuros and uses them for a seminary.

text_headline: A new Church in Taal, Batangas, built near the Caysasay shrine and begun in 1756, is completed by Martin Aguirre, OSA.
text_description: A new Church in Taal, Batangas, built near the Caysasay shrine and begun in 1756, is completed by Martin Aguirre, OSA. The Taal eruption of 1852 will damage the church and convento.

text_headline: Puente de Aritao, aka Puente Antigua and Puente Munting Bayan, in Tayabas, Quezon, is built of stone under Gov Diego Urbino.
text_description: Puente de Aritao, aka Puente Antigua and Puente Munting Bayan, in Tayabas, Quezon, is built of stone under Gov Diego Urbino.

text_headline: Silay’s grand ancestral houses are built around this time as a result of the economic upturn brought by the production of sugar for export.
text_description: Silay’s grand ancestral houses are built around this time as a result of the economic upturn brought by the production of sugar for export.

text_headline: Santa Catalina College in Intramuros is rebuilt.
text_description: Santa Catalina College in Intramuros is rebuilt.

text_headline: The fourth Manila Cathedral is completed.
text_description: The fourth Manila Cathedral is completed. As result of the 1749 Taal eruption, the cathedral is deemed unsafe and is demolished in 1751.

text_headline: Church of the Patrocino in Boljoon, Cebu is constructed. Rococo motifs are evident on the retablo, considered an exemplary of this style.
text_description: Church of the Patrocino in Boljoon, Cebu is constructed. Rococo motifs are evident on the retablo, considered an exemplary of this style.

text_headline: Santa Maria Church in Ilocos Sur is completed.
text_description: Santa Maria Church in Ilocos Sur is completed. It is declared a World Heritage site in 1993.

text_headline: A granite staircase known as Hagdan-hagdan, later renamed San Lorenzo Ruiz steps, connecting the Taal Basilica with the shrine to Our Lady of Caysasay, is built under Fr. Celestino Mayordomo.
text_description: A granite staircase known as Hagdan-hagdan, later renamed San Lorenzo Ruiz steps, connecting the Taal Basilica with the shrine to Our Lady of Caysasay, is built under Fr. Celestino Mayordomo.

text_headline: The sixth Manila Cathedral is completed.
text_description: The sixth Manila Cathedral is completed. The sixth cathedral will collapse during the earthquake of 1863.

text_headline: Puerta de Isabel II, the last gate of Intramuros to be built, is completed, replacing Magallanes, a small gate that leads to the Pasig River.
text_description: Puerta de Isabel II, the last gate of Intramuros to be built, is completed, replacing Magallanes, a small gate that leads to the Pasig River.

text_headline: The “Gift House” in Taal, Batangas is built by Eulalio Villavicencio for his bride, Gliceria Marella, hence the popular name.
text_description: The “Gift House” in Taal, Batangas is built by Eulalio Villavicencio for his bride, Gliceria Marella, hence the popular name.

text_headline: The Dakong Balay heritage house in Carcar, Cebu is renovated around this time.
text_description: The Dakong Balay heritage house in Carcar, Cebu is renovated around this time. It is acquired by the Noel family from a previous owner. It is declared heritage house by NHI in Sept 2009.

text_headline: The Jesuit church and residence in Jolo are built inside Jolo’s walled settlement.
text_description: The Jesuit church and residence in Jolo are built inside Jolo’s walled settlement.

text_headline: The Sagrario chapel beside Manila cathedral is damaged and is never rebuilt.
text_description: The Sagrario chapel beside Manila cathedral is damaged and is never rebuilt.

text_headline: Ermita’s Church of Nuestra Señora de Guia is completed, designed by Lorenzo Guerrero (1835-1904).
text_description: Ermita’s Church of Nuestra Señora de Guia is completed, designed by Lorenzo Guerrero (1835-1904). The church is destroyed during WWII and a new church is built in the 1950s, designed by Carlos Antonio Santos-Viola (1912-1994).

text_headline: TIMES THEATER
text_description: Times Theater in Quiapo, designed by Luis Ma. Araneta, is completed.

text_headline: Villa Angela in Vigan built.
text_description: Villa Angela in Vigan built.

text_headline: La Paz Church of Nuestra Señora de la Paz y Buenviaje in Iloilo is completed.
text_description: La Paz Church of Nuestra Señora de la Paz y Buenviaje in Iloilo is completed. It is rebuilt after WWII.

media_caption: Corpus, now Singson House in Vigan, 1991
text_headline: The Pedro Singson residence in Vigan is completed.
text_description: The Pedro Singson residence in Vigan is completed.

text_headline: The Carriedo Municipal Waterworks begins to conduct water to Manila.
text_description: The Carriedo Municipal Waterworks begins to conduct water to Manila. Begun in 1867 and financed from investments made on a 10,000 peso bequest by Manila governor Francisco de Carriedo y Peredo in 1734, the system brings water from the Marikina River through a series of reservoirs, pipes, and aqueducts. It is designed by Genaro Palacios.

text_headline: The church at Las Mercedes, Zamboanga is completed around this year.
text_description: The church at Las Mercedes, Zamboanga is completed around this year.

text_headline: The Escuela de Niños y Niñas in Dapitan, Zamboanga del Norte, is completed around this year.
text_description: The Escuela de Niños y Niñas in Dapitan, Zamboanga del Norte, is completed around this year.

media_caption: Interior of the 1889 San Ignacio Church in Intramuros, Manila
text_headline: The second San Ignacio, begun in 1879, is completed.
text_description: The second San Ignacio, begun in 1879, is completed. It is designed by Felix Roxas, Sr. in the Neoclassical and Neorennaisance styles. Sculptures are made by Isabelo Tampinco and his workshop.

media_caption: Manila Observatory on Padre Faura Street in Manila
media_credit: Philippine Picture Post Cards: 1900-1920 by Jonathan Best, The Bookmark, Inc, 1994
text_headline: An astronomical observatory is completed at Ermita (Padre Faura St.) for the Manila Observatory.
text_description: An astronomical observatory is completed at Ermita (Padre Faura St.) for the Manila Observatory.

media_caption: Church of Santo Tomas Villanueva in Pardo, Cebu, ca 1990
text_headline: Pardo church in Cebu, commenced in 1880, is completed.
text_description: Pardo church in Cebu, commenced in 1880, is completed.

media_caption: Manila Observatory on Padre Faura Street in Manila
media_credit: (Philippine Picture Post Cards: 1900-1920 by Jonathan Best, The Bookmark, Inc, 1994)
text_headline: Federico Faura SJ establishes the Manila Observatory on the roof of the Jesuits’ Casa Mision in Intramuros.
text_description: Federico Faura SJ establishes the Manila Observatory on the roof of the Jesuits’ Casa Mision in Intramuros. It begins as a meteorological observatory.

media_caption: Train station in Tutuban, Manila
media_credit: Philippine Picture Post Cards: 1900-1920 by Jonathan Best. The Bookmark, Inc, 1994.
text_headline: Tutuban Railroad Station in Manila, is completed. It uses refabricated steel parts manufactured in England.
text_description: Tutuban Railroad Station in Manila, is completed. It uses refabricated steel parts manufactured in England.

media_caption: Stage, orchestra, and balconies of the Teatro Zorrilla, Calle Azcaragga (now Claro M. Recto Avenue), Manila, 1911, where operas, sarsuwela, concerts, and other musical events were held in the first decades of the American period
text_headline: Teatro Circo Zorrilla on Calzada de Iris (now C.M. Recto) is inaugurated.
text_description: Teatro Circo Zorrilla on Calzada de Iris (now C.M. Recto) is inaugurated.

media_caption: View of Dapitan
media_credit: Colorized by Kiko del Rosario, Philippine Picture Post Cards: 1900-1920 by Jonathan Best, The Bookmark, Inc, 1994
text_headline: With Paula de Sanchez, Rizal builds a relief map of Mindanao in the Dapitan plaza.
text_description: With Paula de Sanchez, Rizal builds a relief map of Mindanao in the Dapitan plaza.

media_caption: Lourdes Church after World War II
text_headline: The Capuchin Church of Nuestra Señora de Lourdes in the Romanesque Revival style in Intramuros is completed.
text_description: The Capuchin Church of Nuestra Señora de Lourdes in the Romanesque Revival style in Intramuros is completed.The church is damaged during WWII and not rebuilt. The Capuchins rebuild in Quezon City after WWII.

text_headline: Malaspina’s artists Brambila and Ravenat illustrate principal buildings in Manila, leaving a visual record of what these buildings look like after the British occupation.
text_description: Malaspina’s artists Brambila and Ravenat illustrate principal buildings in Manila, leaving a visual record of what these buildings look like after the British occupation.

text_headline: Chapel of San Vicente Ferrer, in Barangay Cogon, Carcar, Cebu is built.
text_description: Chapel of San Vicente Ferrer, in Barangay Cogon, Carcar, Cebu is built.

text_headline: The Manila Cathedral’s vault collapses, while the cathedral canons are gathered for the Vespers on the Eve of Corpus Christi.
text_description: The Manila Cathedral’s vault collapses, while the cathedral canons are gathered for the Vespers on the Eve of Corpus Christi. Among the casualties is Pablo Pelaez, a diocesan priest noted for his brillance, leadership and advocacy of the rights of the diocesan clergy, most of whom are native Filipinos or mestizos.

media_caption: Taluksangay Mosque, built by the Nuño family
text_headline: Taluksangay Mosque, built by Hadji Abdullah Maas Nuño, becomes a center of Islamic studies and jurisprudence.
text_description: Taluksangay Mosque, built by Hadji Abdullah Maas Nuño, becomes a center of Islamic studies and jurisprudence.

media_caption: Hotel de Oriente
media_credit: Colorized by Eduardo S. Sison, John Tewell Collection
text_headline: Hotel el Oriente, facing Plaza Calderon in Binondo and designed by Juan Hervas, opens.
text_description: Hotel el Oriente, facing Plaza Calderon in Binondo and designed by Juan Hervas, opens. It is the first modern hotel in Manila, with running hot and cold shower and in suite bathrooms, electricity, telephone service, and a restaurant that serves international cuisine.

media_caption: Lazi Convento, Siquijor Island, ca 1990
text_headline: The Lazi Convento of the Recollects in Lazi, Siqujor, is completed.
text_description: The Lazi Convento of the Recollects in Lazi, Siqujor, is completed. The convento has the reputation of being the largest in the Philippines.

media_caption: Cape Bojeador Lighthouse in Ilocos Norte, 2013
text_headline: The Cape Bojeador Lighthouse in Burgos, Ilocos Norte is completed.
text_description: The Cape Bojeador Lighthouse in Burgos, Ilocos Norte is completed.
Humans leave handprints at Alab, Mountain Province.

media_caption: Balay na Tisa or Sarmiento-Osmeña bahay na bato in Carcar, Cebu, 2013, exemplifying arquitectura mestiza
text_headline: The balay na tisa in Carcar, Cebu is built.
text_description: The balay na tisa in Carcar, Cebu is built. It is declared heritage house by NHI on Sep 4, 2009.

text_headline: Puerta Real, formerly at the end of Calle Real del Palacio, is transferred toward the west facing the walls of Colegio de San Jose to improve Intramuros’ defensive capability.
text_description: Puerta Real, formerly at the end of Calle Real del Palacio, is transferred toward the west facing the walls of Colegio de San Jose to improve Intramuros’ defensive capability.

text_headline: The Clarin house in Loay, Bohol is built
text_description: The Clarin house in Loay, Bohol is built; it is named after the family of Aniceto Velez Clarin, gov of Bohol from 1901 to 1904.

text_headline: The Victor Fernandez Gaston heritage house in Silay, Negros Occidental, aka Balay Negrense, is built.
text_description: The Victor Fernandez Gaston heritage house in Silay, Negros Occidental, aka Balay Negrense, is built. It is now a house museum, marked by NHI in 1994.

text_headline: Tamontaka church in Cotabato is built.
text_description: Tamontaka church in Cotabato is built.

text_headline: American soldiers open the first primary school of the American public school system at the site of the Alcaiceria de San Fernando in Binondo.
text_description: American soldiers open the first primary school of the American public school system at the site of the Alcaiceria de San Fernando in Binondo. The school is named Primary School of San Nicolas.

text_headline: US Military Camps are set up in Malate at sites whose streets will be named after the different states from which soldiers have been recruited, like, Pennsylvania, Vermont, Colorado, Nebraska.
text_description: US Military Camps are set up in Malate at sites whose streets will be named after the different states from which soldiers have been recruited, like, Pennsylvania, Vermont, Colorado, Nebraska.

text_headline: Iloilo’s casa real, built in 1840, is named the Iloilo Provincial Capitol. Renovated, it is used as a Japanese garrison during WWII.
text_description: Iloilo’s casa real, built in 1840, is named the Iloilo Provincial Capitol. Renovated, it is used as a Japanese garrison during WWII. It is repaired in the 1960s but damaged by fire in 1998. It is declared a historical site in 2010 and restored by NHCP.

text_headline: Bourne completes the Custom house in Manila, a wooden building with a dome.
text_description: Bourne completes the Custom house in Manila, a wooden building with a dome.

text_headline: Bourne builds a wooden city hall for Manila, based on elements of the bahay na bato.
text_description: Bourne builds a wooden city hall for Manila, based on elements of the bahay na bato. He also builds the Government Laboratory in the Mission Revival style using masonry joined by cement and lime mortar.

text_headline: To open access to the wharfs along the Pasig River
text_description: To open access to the wharfs along the Pasig River, the wall at the end of Calle Real del Palacio, the Bastion de Santo Domingo and its gate, the Almacenes, Maestranza walls from Fort Santiago to San Juan de Letran are demolished.

text_headline: The Liloan Lighthouse in Cebu is completed.
text_description: The Liloan Lighthouse in Cebu is completed. Built of reinforced concrete it is one of the early lighthouses of the American era.

text_headline: Easter School classroom and dormitories are built.
text_description: Easter School classroom and dormitories are built.

text_headline: Ynchausti Merchant House in Iloilo is built.
text_description: Ynchausti Merchant House in Iloilo is built.

text_headline: First of the Baguio School’s buildings, later called Ogilby Hall is built.
text_description: First of the Baguio School’s buildings, later called Ogilby Hall is built. One of the oldest building structures in Baguio, it is marked by NHCP 2011.

media_caption: American-period Silliman Hall of Silliman University in Dumaguete City
text_headline: Silliman Hall in Silliman University in Dumaguete City is built.
text_description: Silliman Hall in Silliman University in Dumaguete City is built.

media_caption: Yap-Sandiego Ancestral House, 2004
text_headline: Yap house in Carcar, Cebu is constructed, later renovated in 1936.
text_description: Yap house in Carcar, Cebu is constructed, later renovated in 1936.

media_caption: American-period Central United Methodist Church
text_headline: Central Methodist church on TM Kalaw is built, designed by Juan Arellano (1888-1960).
text_description: Central Methodist church on TM Kalaw is built, designed by Juan Arellano (1888-1960).

media_caption: The Manila Grand Opera House on Avenida Rizal, Manila ca 1920s
text_headline: Manila Grand Opera House is used as the site of the first National Assembly.
text_description: Manila Grand Opera House is used as the site of the first National Assembly.

media_caption: American-period Mirador Hill
text_headline: The Jesuits build a house on top of Mirador Hill; one wing is used by the Manila Observatory.
text_description: The Jesuits build a house on top of Mirador Hill; one wing is used by the Manila Observatory.

media_caption: American-period Army and Navy Club in Manila
text_headline: The Army-Navy Club at the Luneta, designed by Parsons, is completed.
text_description: The Army-Navy Club at the Luneta, designed by Parsons, is completed.

media_caption: Prewar YMCA Building in Manila
text_headline: YMCA Manila, designed by Parsons, is built.
text_description: YMCA Manila, designed by Parsons, is built.

media_caption: Baguio City Hall, ca 1925
text_headline: The Baguio Government Complex is built using wood.
text_description: The Baguio Government Complex is built using wood. The Baguio City Hall is completed in the Stick-style.

text_headline: Aduana or Custom House in Cebu is built; its design is attributed to Parsons.
text_description: Aduana or Custom House in Cebu is built; its design is attributed to Parsons.

text_headline: Iloilo provincial jail is completed.
text_description: Iloilo provincial jail is completed. In 2017, it undergoes restoration and redevelopment as the Iloilo branch of the National Museum.

text_headline: The Laguna Capitol is completed.
text_description: The Laguna Capitol is completed.

text_headline: Immaculate Conception Church and Ateneo de Zamboanga school buildings are completed.
text_description: Immaculate Conception Church and Ateneo de Zamboanga school buildings are completed.

media_caption: Bradford Memorial Church, ca 1913-24, Cebu City
media_credit: Cebuano Studies Center, University of San Carlos
text_headline: Bradford Memorial Church is completed in Neogothic style.
text_description: Bradford Memorial Church is completed in Neogothic style. It is the oldest Protestant church in Cebu. It is restored in 2013.

media_caption: Prewar Philippine General Hospital in Manila
text_headline: The Philippine General Hospital desgned by Parsons in the Mission Revival style is completed.
text_description: The Philippine General Hospital desgned by Parsons in the Mission Revival style is completed.

media_caption: University of the Philippines along Padre Faura Street, Manila
media_credit: Philippine Picture Post Cards: 1900-1920 by Jonathan Best, The Bookmark, Inc, 1994
text_headline: The UP College of Medicine (Calderon Hall) and the School of Fine Arts and Conservatory of Music (Villamor Hall) is completed.
text_description: The UP College of Medicine (Calderon Hall) and the School of Fine Arts and Conservatory of Music (Villamor Hall) is completed. Juan Arellano designs the building.

media_caption: Elks Club at the foreground and Army and Navy Club at the background before World War II
text_headline: Elks Club in Luneta, Manila, designed by Parsons, is completed.
text_description: Elks Club in Luneta, Manila, designed by Parsons, is completed.

media_caption: Houses in Teachers Camp
text_headline: The first permanent building of Teachers’ Camp in Baguio is raised; this is the mess hall.
text_description: The first permanent building of Teachers’ Camp in Baguio is raised; this is the mess hall.

text_headline: SM Mall of Asia in the Pasay reclamation area and facing Manila Bay is completed.
text_description: SM Mall of Asia in the Pasay reclamation area and facing Manila Bay is completed.

text_headline: The Medical City in Pasig City, designed by Archion, is completed.
text_description: The Medical City in Pasig City, designed by Archion, is completed.
Kalanay-type pottery, named after Kalanay Cave in Aroroy, northwest Masbate, is made.

text_headline: The Malay forge is developed, which is essential for forging metal used in making implements.
text_description: The Malay forge is developed, which is essential for forging metal used in making implements.

text_headline: Development of boat building in SEAsia is documented to this time.
text_description: Development of boat building in SEAsia is documented to this time.

text_headline: European colonization of territories outside Europe begins and spreads European architectural traditions worldwide.
text_description: European colonization of territories outside Europe begins and spreads European architectural traditions worldwide.

text_headline: The Boholano inhabitants abandon dwellings resting on stout wooden piles over the shallows of the Panglao Strait. In Dapitan
text_description: The Boholano inhabitants abandon dwellings resting on stout wooden piles over the shallows of the Panglao Strait. In Dapitan, they build their village under the protective shelter of Ilihan Hill, which they fortify.

text_headline: Philippine Arena
text_description: The Iglesia ni Cristo inaugurates the Philippine Arena in Ciudad Victoria, Bocaue and Santa Maria, Bulacan for the centennial celebration of INC.

text_headline: The historic Cathedral of the Transfiguration of Palo, Leyte and the Church of La Inmaculada Concepcion in Guiuan, Samar are damaged by Typhoon Yolanda.
text_description: The historic Cathedral of the Transfiguration of Palo, Leyte and the Church of La Inmaculada Concepcion in Guiuan, Samar are damaged by Typhoon Yolanda.

media_caption: Ayala Center in Makati City
media_credit: The Sunday Times Magazine, 1966, Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection
text_headline: Ayala Greenbelt is redesigned and remodelled by Recio and Casas to have more open spaces, trees and land
text_description: Ayala Greenbelt is redesigned and remodelled by Recio and Casas to have more open spaces, trees and land

media_caption: Zuellig Building, the first LEED-certified “green” high-rise building in the Philippines, 2016
text_headline: The Zuellig Bldg. in Makati, begun in 2008 and designed by William Coscolluela (b. 1933), is completed.
text_description: The Zuellig Bldg. in Makati, begun in 2008 and designed by William Coscolluela (b. 1933), is completed. It is the first building in the Philippines to receive LEED’s platinum certification as a “green building.”

media_caption: Convention Center in Iloilo City, built in 2015
text_headline: Iloilo Convention Center in Manduriao
text_description: The Iloilo Convention Center in Manduriao, designed by William Coscolluela, is completed for the APEC convention in November.

text_headline: Ferdinand Magellan (1480-1521) encounters bamboo and thatch dwellings of the Cebuano.
text_description: Ferdinand Magellan (1480-1521) encounters bamboo and thatch dwellings of the Cebuano. Antonio de Pigafetta (ca 1491-ca 1531), the chronicler of Magellan, records how the Cebuanos lived and their practices and customs. His is the first European account of a Cebuano village.

media_caption: Lopez Mansion or Nelly Garden in Iloilo City, 2012
text_description: Nelly Garden, aka the Lopez-Hofileña mansion, in Jaro, Iloilo is completed.
The Lal-lo church in Cagayan Valley is built by the Dominicans around this time.

media_caption: Church of San Diego, ca 1990
text_description: The Church of San Diego in Silay, Neg Occidental, is designed in Neoromanesque and Renaissance styles by the Italian architect Lucio Verasconi.

media_caption: Church of San Luis in Pampanga, 2005
text_headline: Before this year, San Luis Church in Pampanga is completed.
text_description: Before this year, San Luis Church in Pampanga is completed.

media_caption: Perez-Samanillo Building, behind bahay na bato on the right, in prewar Escolta
text_description: The Perez-Samanillo Bldg, begun in 1928 and designed by Andres Luna de San Pedro, is completed.

media_caption: Manila Cathedral, ca 1910
text_headline: The seventh Manila Cathedral is finished under the supervision of Arch Luciano Oliver.
text_description: The seventh Manila Cathedral is finished under the supervision of Arch Luciano Oliver. This cathedral in Neoromanesque style is bombed in 1945.

media_caption: La Insular Cigar Factory, ca 1920
text_headline: La Insular Cigarette Factory, designed by Juan Jose Hervas in the Neomudejar style, is established beside the Binondo church.
text_description: La Insular Cigarette Factory, designed by Juan Jose Hervas in the Neomudejar style, is established beside the Binondo church.

media_caption: Don Mariano Mercado House, ca 1990
text_headline: NYOR MERCADO HOUSE
text_description: The Nyor Mercado House in Carcar, Cebu is constructed.

media_caption: Insular Ice Plant in Manila, ca 1920
text_headline: INSULAR ICE PLANT
text_description: The Insular Ice Plant and Cold Storage is built designed by Edgar Ketchum Bourne (a. 1901) in the Neoclassial style. Made of brick, it is located at the foot of Quiapo Bridge on the Pasig's southern bank. It is demolished in 1984 to make way for LRT 1.

media_caption: Balay Negrense Museum in Silay City, 2017
text_headline: BALAY NEGRENSE
text_description: The Victor Fernandez Gaston heritage house in Silay, Negros Occidental, aka Balay Negrense, is built. It is now a house museum, marked by NHI in 1994.

media_caption: Prewar Ayuntamiento or City Hall in Intramuros
media_credit: Philippine Picture Post Cards: 1900-1920 by Jonathan Best. The Bookmark, Inc, 1994.
text_headline: The third Ayuntamiento, also known as Casas Consistoriales or Cabildo (Manila’s City Hall), in Intramuros is most likely completed after this year.
text_description: The third Ayuntamiento, also known as Casas Consistoriales or Cabildo (Manila’s City Hall), in Intramuros is most likely completed after this year. Various architects work on this building, namely: Eduardo Lopez Navarro, Felix A, Roxas Sr. (c. 1820-c. 1890), Juan Hervas (active 1885-d. early 20th century).

media_caption: Manila Observatory on Padre Faura Street in Manila
media_credit: Philippine Picture Post Cards: 1900-1920 by Jonathan Best, The Bookmark, Inc, 1994
text_headline: Ruperto Ibañez designs the Neoclassical buildings for the Manila Observatory at Ermita.
text_description: Ruperto Ibañez designs the Neoclassical buildings for the Manila Observatory at Ermita.

media_caption: Goldenberg Mansion facade in Manila, 2011
media_credit: National Historical Commission of the Philippines Collection
text_headline: The Goldenberg Mansion in San Miguel, Manila is constructed.
text_description: The Goldenberg Mansion in San Miguel, Manila is constructed. During martial law (1972-1981), it is refurbished and used as a Malacañan guest house in the San Miguel district.

media_caption: Central nave, lateral aisles, vaulted ceiling, and stained glass windows of the Church of San Sebastian in Quiapo, Manila, 2013
media_credit: Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection
text_headline: The Recollects complete the all-steel San Sebastian church in Quiapo, designed by Genaro Palacios.
text_description: The Recollects complete the all-steel San Sebastian church in Quiapo, designed by Genaro Palacios. It uses prefabricated steel parts imported from Europe.

media_caption: Casa Redonda, rebuilt according to the plans of the original octagonal hut by Jose Rizal
text_headline: Jose Rizal builds houses in Talisay, Dapitan, Zamboanga del Norte.
text_description: Jose Rizal builds houses in Talisay, Dapitan, Zamboanga del Norte. He builds a residence, a school, and the casa redonda, an octagonal house for a clinic. Then he begins the waterworks for Talisay with the assistance of Bro. Juan Costa, SJ in preparation for his model farm which will use modern methods of agriculture.

media_caption: Church of Santiago
text_headline: Dapitan Church of Santiago in Zamboanga del Norte is completed.
text_description: Dapitan Church of Santiago in Zamboanga del Norte is completed.

media_caption: Kennon Road to Baguio, popularly known as the Zigzag, ca 1915
text_headline: Kennon Rd is completed, as are the lagoon in Burnham Park and the Baguio Country Club, the latter in Stick-style using wood and thatch.
text_description: Kennon Rd is completed, as are the lagoon in Burnham Park and the Baguio Country Club, the latter in Stick-style using wood and thatch.

media_caption: Prewar Mansion House
text_headline: The Mansion House in Baguio, designed by William E. Parsons (b. 1872-1939) in the Neoclassical style and constructed as official summer residence of American governor general, is completed.
text_description: The Mansion House in Baguio, designed by William E. Parsons (b. 1872-1939) in the Neoclassical style and constructed as official summer residence of American governor general, is completed. And so are the Baguio General Hospital, designed by Parsons and begun in 1907; 80 residential cottages at government center in Baguio; and the Baguio Market of wood at the juncture of Session Road and Magsaysay.

media_caption: Prewar Manila Hotel
text_headline: Manila Hotel, designed by Parsons and begun in 1909, is inaugurated.
text_description: Manila Hotel, designed by Parsons and begun in 1909, is inaugurated.

media_caption: Don Francisco Barrios residence, built in the 1860s, now Bank of the Philippine Islands Zamboanga main office, 2017
text_headline: BPI opens branch at Zamboanga at the ground floor of a house built by Don Francisco Barrios in the 1870s
text_description: BPI opens branch at Zamboanga at the ground floor of a house built by Don Francisco Barrios in the 1870s and renovated as the official residence of Gov Maj John “Black Jack” Pershing.

media_caption: Art noveau Mariano Uy-Chaco Building, built 1914, now Philtrust Bank Building in Escolta
text_description: The Uy Chaco (Philtrust) building in the art noveau style, in Binondo, is completed.

media_caption: Prewar Gotiaoco Building
media_credit: Sugbu Chinese Heritage Museum, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection
text_description: Gotiaoco Bldg. is completed. It is the first building in Cebu to have an elevator.

media_caption: American-period Philippine Normal School in Manila
text_description: The Philippine Normal School (now PNU), designed by Parsons, is built in the Mission revival and Neoclassical styles.

media_caption: Dominican Hill
text_description: The Dominican residence, begun in 1913 and designed by Roque Ruaño, OP (1877-1935) is completed on Dominican Hill, Baguio. In 1973 the Dominicans sell the property and it becomes Diplomat Hotel. In 2005, the ruined building and property is acquired by Baguio City and is renamed Heritage and Nature Park. The house is marked by NHCP in 2014.

media_caption: Prewar Legislative Building in Manila
text_description: The National Library, designed by Doane and Toledo of the Bureau of Public Works, is completed. Appropriated for use by the Philippine Legislature in 1926, Juan Arellano renovates the building. Badly damaged during WWII, it is restored but with less opulence. It funtions as the Philippine Congress until the lower House of Representatives moves to the Batasang Pambansa in Quezon City in 1987 and the Senate to the Government Service Issurance System (GSIS) building in 1997. The 1998 National Museum Act of 1998 mandates that the National Museum acquire the Congress, Agriculture, and Finance buildings. Congress becomes the National Museum of Fine Arts in 2000.

media_caption: Pangasinan Capitol Building in Lingayen City, 1990
text_description: The Lingayen Provincial Capitol in Pangasinan, begun in 1917 and designed by Ralph Doane, is completed. In Neoclassical style, it is noted for its Grecian temple facade with Ionic columns.

media_caption: Luneta Hotel to the left and Bayview Hotel to the right before World War II
text_description: Luneta Hotel, designed by Salvador Ferre in the French Renaissance style, is completed. It is characterized by a Mansard roof. It survives WWII and functions as a hotel until it is closed in 1987. It is marked by the NHCP in 2014.

media_caption: Leyte Capitol in Tacloban City, ca 1990
text_description: Toledo designs UP College of Medicine Annex and University Library, and the Leyte Capitol.

media_caption: Saint Catherine’s Academy in Carcar, Cebu, ca 1990
text_description: St Catherine’s Academy (P. del Corro Bldg) in Carcar, Cebu is completed.

media_caption: Pacific Commercial Company Building, 1968
media_credit: American Geographical Society Library, John Tewell Collection
text_description: Pacific Commercial Co. Bldg. in Escolta is completed.

media_caption: Ward in Philippine General Hospital, Manila, ca 1912
text_description: The Nurses’ Home at PGH, Manila is completed in the Neorenaissance style. Begun in 1915, its architect is Tomas Mapua (1888-1965).

media_caption: The dispensary in Carcar, now a museum, 2016
text_description: Carcar Dispensary, now the Carcar Museum, is completed.

media_caption: 1930 Insular Life Building in Binondo
media_credit: National Library of the Philippines Collection
text_description: Insular Life Bldg. is completed in Binondo, designed by William James Odom and Fernando de la Cantera.

media_caption: American-period Central Post Office in Manila
media_credit: University of the Philippines Main Library Collection
text_description: The Central Post Office on Liwasang Bonifacio, Manila, designed by Juan Arellano and Mapua, is completed.

media_caption: Metropolitan Theater, ca 1930
media_credit: Colorized by Bilog Bilugan, John Tewell Collection
text_description: Metropolitan Theater in Manila is inaugurated. Its architects, Juan and Otilio Arellano (1916-1981), design it in Art Deco. Its sculptures are by Francesco Monti and paintings by Fernando Amorsolo. Reconstructed and renovated, it is reinaugurated in 1978. Acquired by NCCA in 2015, it is undergoing restoration.

media_caption: Prewar Crystal Arcade in Escolta, Manila
text_description: Crystal Arcade in Art Deco, designed by Luna de San Pedro, at Escolta is inaugurated. It is the first retail and office building to have underground parking.

media_caption: Lobby of Saint Cecilia’s Hall, Saint Scholastica’s College in Manila, 2014
text_description: St. Scholastica’s College on Pennsylvania (now Leon Guinto) St, designed by Luna de San Pedro in the Neoromanesque style, is completed.

media_caption: Ideal and State Theaters along Avenida Rizal, Manila
text_description: The Ideal Theater on Rizal Ave, Manila, designed by Pablo Antonio (1902-1975), is completed.

media_caption: Maria Ledesma Golez House in Silay City before restoration
text_description: The Angel Araneta Ledesma house and the Maria Golez house, both in Silay, Negros Occidental, are completed.

media_caption: Central Seminary Building of the University of Santo Tomas, ca 1940
text_description: UST Central Seminary, designed by Fernando H. Ocampo (1897-1984) in Art Deco, is completed.

media_caption: Agrifina Circle between the former Agriculture and Finance Buildings
text_description: The twin buildings of the Departments of Agriculture and Finance, facing Agrifina Circle, begun in 1930 and designed by Toledo, are completed. These buildings are turned over to the National Museum, which reuses Finance for the Museum of Anthropology or the Museum of the Filipino People in 1998. Agriculture, used by the Department of Tourism, is turned over in 2013. It is restored and reused as the Museum of Natural History.

media_caption: Municipal Hall of Jaro, Iloilo, restored in 2017 by the National Museum
text_description: The Art Deco Jaro Municipal building, designed by Juan Arellano, is completed. It is restored in 2017 as the National Museum of the Philippines regional office.

media_caption: Prewar art deco-style Rizal Memorial Stadium in Manila
text_description: The Rizal Memorial Stadium in Art Deco on Vito Cruz (Pablo Ocampo) St., designed by the Bureau of Public Works, is completed. Begun in 1932, it is built for the Far Eastern Championship Games, forerunner of the ASEAN Games.

media_caption: Iloilo Provincial Capitol, ca 1915
text_description: A new Iloilo City Hall, begun in 1933, is completed. It is designed by Juan Arellano in Neoclassical style, with sculptures by Francesco Monti (1888-1958).

media_caption: Cathedral of Our Lady of the Atonement
text_description: The Baguio Church of Our Lady of the Atonement on Kampo hill, officially named cathedral in 1935, is completed this year. It is predominantly Neogothic although Roman arches are used in the facade and bell tower. Florimund Carlu, CICM, is responsible for the project.

media_caption: Caida and sala of the Lizares House in Talisay, Negros Occidental, ca 1990
text_description: The Lizares-Alunan residence in Talisay, Negros Occ is completed.

media_caption: De La Salle College before World War II
text_description: De La Salle University, designed by Mapua in the Neoclassical style, is completed.

media_caption: Cebu Provincial Capitol, 2016
text_description: The Cebu City Hall in the Federal style is completed.

media_caption: Cebu Provincial Capitol, 2016
text_description: The Cebu Provincial Capitol is completed. Designed by Toledo in the Stripped Classicism variation of Art Deco, it is the terminus of a wide avenue.

media_caption: View of Osmeña Ave with the Rizal Library, left, and the Cebu Provincial Capitol at far end, ca 1950
text_description: The Jose Rizal Memorial Library is constructed in Cebu, along Osmeña Ave. It is Neorenaissance withan elevated logia.

media_caption: Jai-Alai Building in Manila, 1952
text_description: Jai-Alai, in Streamline Moderne style, is completed, designed by the American architects, Walter C. Wurdeman (1903-1949) and Welton David Becket (1902-1969).

media_caption: Tsalet or chalet-style private residence in Camp John Hay, Baguio City, ca 1920
text_description: The American High Commisioner’s residence is constructed in Camp John Hay, Baguio. With independence it is turned over to the American ambassador. It is marked by NHCP in 2005.

media_caption: Diosdado Lorenzo, Atrocities in Paco
text_description: No major architectural projects are undertaken during World War II.

media_caption: Adamson University, ca 1950
text_description: Adamson University, founded in 1932, transfers to new buildings at San Marcelino campus.

media_caption: Former city hall of Iloilo, now the University of the Philippines Visayas
media_credit: The University of the Philippines: A University for Filipinos, edited by Gloria D. Feliciano. Diamond Jubilee Presidential Commission, 1984.
text_description: The former Iloilo City Hall, built 1933 to 1935, is turned over to UP Iloilo by Fernando Lopez.

media_caption: Chapel of the Holy Sacrifice in the University of the Philippines Diliman, showing its thin-shell concrete dome, 1989
text_description: The UP Chapel of the Holy Sacrifice, planned in 1947, is completed. It is a modernist church, designed by Leandro V. Locsin (1928-1994) with art works by Arturo Luz, Vicente Manansala, and Napoleon “Billy” Abueva.

media_caption: Araneta Coliseum in Cubao, Quezon City, ca 1960
text_description: The Araneta Coliseum, begun in 1957, is completed. Called the “Big Dome,” its architect is Dominador Lacson Lugtu and engineer is Leonardo Onjunco Lugtu.

media_caption: Interior of the Manila Cathedral, showing altar, vaulted ceiling, nave, and lateral aisles, 1993
media_credit: Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection
text_description: The eighth Manila Cathedral, begun in 1954, is inaugurated. F.H. Ocampo is head architect in charge of design and supervision. Teams of Italian and Filipino artists work on the interior. Stained glass design is by Galo Ocampo (1913-1965).

media_caption: Philippine-American Life Insurance Company Building in Manila, built in 1961
text_description: The Philam Life Insurance Bldg on Isaac Peral Ave (later United Nations Ave), designed by Carlos Arguelles (1917-2008), is completed.

media_caption: Meralco Building, built in 1936
text_description: The Meralco Bldg on Ortigas Ave. in Pasig City, designed by Jose Zaragoza, is completed.

media_caption: Luneta Hotel to the left and Bayview Hotel to the right before World War II
text_description: In preparation for the meeting, high rise, five-star hotels are built. Roads are improved.

media_caption: San Miguel Corporation Building in Mandaluyong City, 2008
text_headline: ENVIRONMENT-FRIENDLY BUILDING
text_description: San Miguel Corporation Head Office, designed by Francisco Ma - osa, is completed. It is characterized as an environment-friendly building, which minimizes the use of electricity.

media_caption: Chapel of the Monastery of the Transfiguration in Malaybalay, Bukidnon, 2017
text_description: The Benedictine Monastery and Chapel of the Transfiguration, designed by Locsin in Malaybalay, Bukidnon, is completed. This is Locsin’s last major work.

media_caption: Pacific Star Building in Makati City, 1991
text_description: Various high rise office and multiuse buildings are completed, namely: Pacific Star in Makati City, designed by Formoso, as a pioneer in post-modern architecture, Tower One of the Makati Stock Exchange, designed by Locsin and SOM, and King’s Court II also in Makati, designed by Rogelio Villarosa (b. 1933).

media_caption: Prewar cottages in Camp John Hay
