text_description: As a result of RA no. 7227, the following government-owned areas are redeveloped as multiple use areas: Subic Naval Station, Subic Bay, Zambales; Clark Airbase, Pampanga; Camp John Hay, Baguio; and Fort Bonifacio (formerly, the American Fort McKinley), Taguig, Rizal. As multiuse developments funded by private enterprise, they are turned into, among others, residential, commercial, manufacturing, educational, tourism-oriented areas.

media_caption: Cathedral Museum of Cebu, 2013
text_description: The restoration of the Cebu rectory under arch Melva Hava begins. The 19th century bahay na bato is reused as the Cathedral Museum of Cebu.

media_caption: Church of the Gesù inside the Ateneo de Manila University campus, 2017
text_description: Ateneo de Manila University’s Church of the Gesù, designed by Jose Recio and Carmelo Casas, is completed.

media_caption: View of prewar Iloilo City
text_description: Iloilo port is opened to international trade, facilitating the export of sugar.

media_caption: Santo Niño Basilica and Monastery in Cebu City
media_credit: A Philippine Album: American Era Photographs 1900-1930 by Jonathan Best, The Bookmark, Inc, 1998
text_headline: Massive destruction happens to both modern and historic buildings in the Visayas.
text_description: Massive destruction happens to both modern and historic buildings in the Visayas. In Cebu, the Santo Niño Basilica’s bell tower collapses. Neighboring churches like Naga suffer damage. Commercial buildings in Tagbilaran, Bohol collapse. Of the 26 historic Bohol churches affected, a number are severely damaged, namely: Baclayon, Loay, Loboc, Loon and Maribojoc. Also the Castillo de San Vicente Ferrer in Punta Cruz is damaged. Loon falls into a sink hole; Maribojoc is split in half because a fault line runs across the church nave.
Wood carving and weaving are introduced to the Philippines.
Gov-Gen Santiago de Vera (r. 1584-1589) requires all buildings in Manila to be built of stone.
The first Dominican church in Intramuros is completed, a provisional structure of light material begun on Aug 6, 1587.
Gov-Gen Gomez Perez Dasmariñas (r. 1590-1593) begins improving the fortification of Manila.
The second Manila Cathedral, now made of stone is completed in 1591 but destroyed by earthquake in 1600.
An ivory image of the Santisimo Rosario, made by a Chinese convert in Manila, is enshrined in the Dominican church in Intramuros.
The Colegio de Santa Potenciana building behind San Agustin church is completed. It is a boarding school for girls.
Church of San Juan Bautista, Taytay, begun in 1600, is completed.
A fort is constructed in Catbalogan, Samar, behind the Church of San Bartolome.

media_caption: A section of Tabon Cave, 2015
text_description: Tabon Caves are inhabited by humans.
Humans use a rock shelter in Binangonan, Rizal where they make carvings on the rock surface, now called the Angono petroglyph. They are dated to the Neolithic period.

media_caption: Manunggul jar
text_description: The human practice of secondary burial is indicated by the Manunggul Jar, found in the Tabon Caves, Palawan. Designated as a National Treasure by the NMP, it depicts on its lid the human soul on a journey to the after life. Curling wave patterns on the jar’s body and a boat with wide-eyed figures suggest that the journey is over water.
Legazpi founds the Ciudad Santisimo Nombre de Jesus at the site named Sug-bu. A triangular palisade is built to protect the ciudad.
The Augustinians, who accompanied Legazpi, establish the Convento of Santisimo Nombre de Jesus (aka Santo Niño). They build the first Catholic church and priory complex in the Philippines.

The galleon trade is not just a trading route; it is also a conduit of architectural and artistic knowledge from Spain and Hispanic America, via Mexico. It brings books, engravings, and prototypes that serve as instructional material and learning tools. But most importantly, through the galleon arrive friars, missionaries, civil servants, engineers and architects versed in the European tradition of building.
In preparation for Limahong’s attack, Manila is surrounded with a makeshift wall made of whatever material was found suitable, like barrels, wooden palisades, sacks of sand and gravel.

Frs Juan de Plasencia (d. 1590) and Diego de Oropesa (a. 1578, d. 1590), OFM found the towns in Laguna and Tayabas, where they build churches of light material. Like these churches, the structures built in Manila and in the newly established missions are of wood, bamboo, and thatch. These materials characterize church construction from the late 1500 to the mid-1600.
First Manila Cathedral is completed. The temporary church of wood and thatch, built by secular priest Juan de Vivero (a. 1556), is destroyed by the fire of 1583.
Bp. Salazar resides in a temporary house of bamboo and nipa. He uses the church of 1579 as a cathedral.
Sedeño is actively involved in construction in Manila from 1581 to 1595.
The temporary Church of Santisimo Rosario in Binondo is built by the Dominicans for the Chinese Christians under their ministry.
Fr. Sedeño, who is credited with introducing Hispanic traditions of building in the Philippines, dies in Cebu.
The Colegio de Manila buildings, consisting of a residence and a school, are constructed in Intramuros.
The Nuestra Señora de los Angeles, mother church of the Franciscans, is built in Intramuros.
San Miguel church at Isla de Provisor on the Pasig burns. The mission’s administration is transferred to the Jesuits.

Being late comers, the Recollects build their church and convent outside the walls at Bagumbayan. However, the Recollects are able to occupy a 12,000 square meter lot at the southeast corner of Intamuros. It has a pipe organ built by Diego Cera, OAR. The chrch was destroyed in 1945.
Dominicans finish rebuiling their church in Intramuros strong enough to support a stone vault after the roof of an earlier church caught fire in 1603.
The third Manila Cathedral, also of stone, is completed at the initiative of Abp Miguel de Benavides, OP. In 1645, it is destroyed by earthquake.
The stone church of the Santisimo Rosario in Binondo is built. By the 18th century, it is replaced by a well-built church designed by Domingo de la Cruz Gonzales.
A bastioned stone fort replaces Fort San Pedro in Iloilo. It is demolished by the Americans in the early 20th century.
Because it is exposed to slave raids, the village of Siaro is transferred in land to Carcar or Cabcar and the old town name forgotten.

The Jesuit novitiate and church, dedicated to San Pedro, are completed on Buenavista hill, overlooking the Pasig River. In 1622, the novices occupy the building. The church still stands, renamed as the Parish of San Pedro.
Malabon church nave is constructed. A transept is added in 1835; the facade is renovated in 1861, with the addition of a Greek temple-type façade by Arch. Luciano Oliver (active C. 1854-1873).
The Augustinian’s Guadalupe Monastery in Makati is completed; it is damaged during WWII and rebuilt in 1970.
The Colegio de San Ildefonso, designed by Campioni, and the Church of Nuestra Señora de Loreto at Cavite Puerto (Cavite City) are inaugurated.
The first church of Dapitan, probably made of stone, is built with the assistance of the descendants of Datu Pagbuya, Pedro Manuel Manoc (Mano-oc).
The Manila Cathedral built by Benavides is destroyed during the earthquake.

After the 1645 earthquake, a hybrid architecture (arquitectura mestiza) develops, which replaces the stone vaults of European architecture with a lighter roof of timber and thatch, eventually replaced by terra cotta tiles. The structure has a lower story of stone and an upper story of wood.
The stone cathedral of Nueva Segovia (Lal-lo), Cagayan Valley, begun in 1653, is completed. Damaged in 1719, it is replaced by a temporary church in 1721.
Ignacio Alzina, SJ describes Philippine colonial houses as “arquitectura mestiza,” hybrid structures of stone for the ground floor and wood for the upper floors.
Ternate church, Cavite, is built in honor of the Santo Niño. Ternate is populated by Christianized Merdekas who leave Ternate, Indonesia for Cavite, when the Spanish garrison is closed.
Tanauan church in Leyte is completed. The church is fortified with a perimeter wall and bastions.
The fourth Manila Cathedral, begun in 1659 by Abp Miguel de Poblete (r. 1653-1667), is completed under Abp Diego Camacho (r. 1697-1705).
Indang’s Church of San Gregorio Magno in Cavite is built around this year.
San Mateo Church of Nuestra Señora de Aranzazu in Rizal is completed.
Palo Church of La Transfiguracion del Señor and the Abuyog Church of San Francisco Xavier, both in Leyte, are completed.
Church of the Venerable Tercera Orden (VOT) is built perpendicular to the Francisan church of Nuestra Señora de los Angeles in Intramuros.
Before this year, a fortification is built on Ilihan Hill, Dapitan.
The Falsabraga de Santa Catalina in Fort Santiago, Manila, is built.
Sariaya’s Church of Santa Cruz in Laguna is completed at a new site, the same one the town of Sariaya presently occupies.
The galleon trade between Manila and Mexico brings in a flow of goods, plants, people, and cultural forms, such as the Moriones mask.

media_caption: Interior of the Church of Santiago Apostol in Betis, Pampanga, 2016
text_description: The Church of Santiago in Betis, Pampanga is completed.

media_caption: Walls of Intramuros
media_credit: (Philippine Picture Post Cards: 1900-1920 by Jonathan Best, The Bookmark, Inc, 1994)
text_description: Following the Renaissance grid plan, the city of Manila is laid out by Legazpi. At this point the walls that will characterize Manila are not yet built; instead the palisaded enclosure of Fort Santiago is built at the site of Sulayman’s kuta, while the rest of the city has no defenses.

media_caption: Church of the Inmaculada Concepcion in Baclayon, Bohol, 2012
text_description: Baclayon Church of La Inmaculada Concepcion in Bohol is completed around this time. It is damaged by the 2013 earthquake but is subsequently restored.

media_caption: Western side facade of the Coconut Palace
text_description: The Coconut Palace, aka Tahanang Pilipino, designed by Francisco Mañosa (b. 1931), is completed. It is renovated in 2010 and becomes the official residence and office of the vice-president.
